thread.title: Milwaukee movies off the grid: Oct. 9-15
thread.title_full: Milwaukee movies off the grid: Oct. 9-15

title: Milwaukee movies off the grid: Oct. 9-15
text:
Milwaukee movies off the grid: Oct. 9-15 Oct. 8, 2015 1:53 p.m. Kirk Douglas stars in “Ace in the Hole.” 
Here are some of the movies showing at alternative venues this week. UWM Union Cinema 
Unless otherwise noted, admission is $5, free for UWM students. 
"Queen of Earth": Indie horror-melodrama by Alex Ross Perry stars Elisabeth Moss and Katherine Waterston as friends whose relationship unravels as madness takes its toll. 7 p.m. Friday, 9:30 p.m. Saturday and 5 p.m. Sunday. 
"Faces": John Cassavetes' 1968 meditation on infidelity and its ripples, with Gena Rowlands, Seymour Cassel, Lynn Carlin, John Marley. 9 p.m. Friday, and 7 p.m. Saturday and Sunday. 
"From the Archives: To See the Sky With the Naked Eye": Collection of films that capture the stars, and beyond. 7 p.m. Tuesday. Free. 
"Planetary": A movie exploring the planet's, and humanity's, origins, followed by a panel discussion on the intersection between faith and the environment. 7 p.m. Wednesday. 
2200 E. Kenwood Blvd.; cinema.uwm.edu FOCUS Film Society 
"Chimes at Midnight": A rare screening of Orson Welles' masterful 1965 blending of five Shakespeare plays, centering on the character of Falstaff, played by Welles. 7 p.m. Saturday at Church in the City, 2648 N. Hackett Ave. $3. Classic Art Films / Gallery 2622 
"Ace in the Hole": Billy Wilder's smart, cynical 1951 gem with Kirk Douglas as a reporter who, itching to return to the big time, turns a story about a man stuck in a cave into a media circus. 7:30 p.m. Tuesday. Free. 
2622 N. Wauwatosa Ave., Wauwatosa; classicartfilms.com 30th annual Milwaukee LGBT Film/Video Festival 
"From This Day Forward": The festival begins Thursday at the Landmark Oriental Theatre, 2230 N. Farwell Ave., with this documentary about filmmaker Sharon Shattuck and her family, and the changes they face when her father comes out as transgender. Shattuck and her father, Trisha, will be at the screening at 7:30 p.m. Thursday. Tickets are $15, $10 for students and seniors 60 and older. (The festival runs through Oct. 25, with subsequent screenings at UWM Union Cinema.)
